journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Analysis of annulus-shaped compliant pivot with series–parallel leaves

contrib-group.aff: Robotics Institute, Beihang University, Beijing, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Tao Qiao, Robotics Institute, Beihang University, 37 Xueyuan Road, Beijing, 100191, PR China. Email: qiaotao21@yahoo.com.cn

abstract.p: Annulus-shaped compliant pivot, formed by well-proportioned compliant modules between the outer ring and inner ring, can be employed in precision mechanical systems due to good performances. Especially for the multi-series leaves in one module, the annulus-shaped compliant pivot can fulfill a large displacement range without any axial drift in theory. In the design of the annulus-shaped compliant pivot, the load–displacement behavior and the stress analysis with analytical forms are important consideration. However, in the literature, there is few detailed work. In this article, a general annulus-shaped compliant pivot model formed by series–parallel leaves is first analytically established for the load–displacement behavior and the stress prediction. These calculations are based on accurate approximation of a beam flexure. Firstly, a loaded moment is decomposed into universal loads by combining the geometric compatibility condition. The stiffness accurate approximation is then analytically obtained, which provides a simple design strategy. Furthermore, the stresses in every leaf are obtained so that the annulus-shaped compliant pivot with large motion range can be actualized by stress checking. Lastly, the analytical model has been verified by commercial finite element analysis software ANSYS.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As is well known, compliant pivots are extensively used because they possess some inherent advantages over the traditional joints such as monolithic manufacturing, ease of assembly, light weight, no backlash, no lubrication, diminished wear, smooth motion, and increased reliability.1,2 Based on the aforementioned merits, compliant pivots are widely used in the fields of precision engineering,3–5 aerospace research,6 industrial fields,7,8 etc.

In the past half century, many kinds of compliant pivots have been proposed and researched, most of which consisted of notch-type pivots and leaves. However, the small motion range of notch-type hinges greatly restricts the application domain. More and more attention has been focused on the compliant pivots structured by leaves. Both notch-type pivots and leaf-type pivots, and some main general indices are considered including stiffness characteristic, motion range, axial drift, etc.9

Stiffness characteristic: Stiffness characteristic includes the axis stiffness and the off-axis stiffness. The stiffness characteristic could foresee the displacement by a specific load condition. Off-axis stiffness, as large as possible, is commonly expected for getting a perfect constraint. The focused stiffness in this article is the axis stiffness because of the special setting. Customarily, an analytical stiffness characteristic is always desired for simplifying the compliant pivot design.

Range of motion: The finite range of a compliant pivot motion is the index of the rigid counterparts rotation angles or translation distances. The motion range is limited by the permissible stresses and strains in the compliant parts material. The stress should be checked by the yield stress in compliant pivots analysis. A confirmed large motion range is come-hither.

Axial drift: Axial drift or parasitic motion is considered as index of the compliant pivot motion precision. Axial drift, which associates with constraint behaviors, was not defined unifiable. If the degree of constraint (DOC) of compliant pivot is not well defined as a rigid pivot, axial drift or parasitic motion cannot be avoided. The parasitic motion can be minimized by adopting symmetrical structure, but the stiffness of ‘degree of freedom (DOF)’ will increase correspondingly; meanwhile, the structure needs more space.

Thus, a compliant pivot with no axial drift, large motion range, and analytical stiffness characteristic is fascinating. The annulus-shaped compliant pivot (ASCP), which is a typical compliant revolute (CR) joint, is competent for these demands. The axial dimension of ASCP is always smaller than other types of CR joints leading to a compact structure. In an ASCP, flexure elements of annulus-shaped compliant pivot are proportionately distributed between the inner and outer ring. The structure character leads to no-axial-drift in center of rotation. If the ASCP is installed with co-axial, zero axial drift is actually achieved.

In the past, several idiographic structures were proposed and employed. A rotary flexure patent was propounded10 in 2000. This design is based on straight beam flexure elements (SBFEs). The DOC is always strengthened leading to a limited rotation range. In order to enlarge the rotation range, curved beam flexure elements (CBFEs) configurations are presented.11–13 The released constraint of the curved beam is always limited along the axial direction. Meanwhile, it is difficult to obtain analytical equations. Consequently, in order to further extend the motion capability, the flexure elements in series are adopted. Swiss Center for Electronics and Micro-technology (CSEM) designed a flexure bearing14 with a series structure. This kind of ASCP lengthened the axial dimension. Bi et al.15 designed a series–parallel ASCP with spokewise multi-leaves, but the analytical equations of the characteristics are difficult to acquire. Sung et al.16 proposed two ASCPs to improve the efficacy of ankle complex (AJC) injury diagnosis and treatment. Recently, a rotary flexure bearing was provided.17 This design offered large angular displacement, low operating stress, low operating torque, and high stiffness in five noncompliant degrees of freedom.

Many of them can be seen in practical applications; however, few analytical equations are derived for the parametric design. The intractable reason is the complex structures, which lead to a rock-ribbed parameter coupling. Notwithstanding, the ASCP with curved beam provided some equations, where the relative errors are always large. Further researches are obligatory.

This article focuses on such an ASCP with series–parallel leaves. Within such a structure (Figure 1(a)), the leaves for each module are in series. All the modules between the outer ring and the inner ring are shunt-wound. That is why such a structure is called series–parallel complaint pivot. The module quantities can be chosen freely according to the designer’s need. Figure 1(b) shows the setting with an end cap. Within such structure, the off-axis loads will not affect the rotation. So, the pivot rotates with a fixed rotational center (the shaft axis), that is why the ASCP has no axial drift. Figure 1.
(a) Annulus-shaped compliant pivots with series–parallel leaves, and (b) co-axial setup structure without axial drift.

In this article, since only the module characteristics are analyzed and not the whole ASCP, the designers could calculate ASCP with selected module quantity. A general analytical module model with 2n+1 leaves and a degenerative model with 2n leaves are established. The stiffness and motion range of these analytical models are analyzed based on a simple beam theory. The results of general model and degenerative model are verified by finite element analysis (FEA) with the leaf quantities of each module being 5 and 4, respectively. The simulation results represent the validity of the analytical model, which enables quick design calculations.

sec.title: The load–displacement behavior of an annulus-shaped compliant pivot
A leaf model
sec.p:
The leaf characteristic model should be established before modeling the annulus compliant pivot with multi-leaves. A uniform-thickness leaf can be regarded as deformed beam undergoing the state of plain strain. The well-known Euler’s formula can be used in solving such a problem. Awtar et al.18 presented some accurate approximation, which provides an effective method in understanding the performance characteristics. Some closed-form results used in this article are arranged as follows (Figure 2). (1)[fm]=[12-6-64][δyθ] +p[6/5-1/10-1/102/15][δyθ] Figure 2.
A beam flexure.

The parameters in the above equations are dimensionless form which are defined as p=PL2EI f=FL2EI m=MLEI δy=ΔyL where M is the carrier moment of the beam, F and P are the tangential load and axial load, respectively; Δy and θ denote the resulting displacements of the beam end; L and W are the length and width of the beam, respectively, I is the second axial moment of area about the Z-axis, and E is the Young’s modulus of the material.

sec.title: Torque–rotation relationship for the annulus-shaped compliant pivot
sec.p:
As can be seen in Figure 3, there are three modules in the ASCP. For simplifying the illustration, the distance between every two adjacent leaves, named D, is omitted in the equations because their dimensions are far less than the effective compliant dimension. We assume that the width and thickness for leaves are the same. Figure 3.
(a) A generalized annulus-shaped compliant pivot with series–parallel leaves, and (b) the exploded view for the load and displacements.

Within such a structure, we assume that the outer ring is fixed, and a torque is applied on the inner moving rigid part, the pivot will rotate with an angle θ. Because of the complexity of the model, just one rotation direction is considered in this article as shown in Figure 3. The horizontal force and vertical force are not considered because these forces applied on the rotation shaft will work as moment effect to the compliant behavior in a co-axial setup. Without loss of generality, each module has a leaf number 2n+1. The leaf, which connects with the inner rigid part, is named number 1, the series-wound leaves are named 2 to2n+1. Global coordinate oxy and local coordinate oixiyi, in the load and displacement equations can be normalized with respect to the properties of each leaf.

When the load torque is applied on the inner part of rotation, the analytical characteristics will be resolved based on the load equilibrium condition, geometric compatibility condition and constitutive relationship. The applied torque M can be decomposed into general forces (Md,Fd,Pd) in the point where the number 1 leaf connects the inner rigid part according to Figure 3. In the following equations, the dimensionless parameters are nondimensionalized with respect to the length and rigidity of leaf-spring 1. (2)m=md+fdγcosθ+pdγsinθ
Here, γ is the ratio between inner radius r and L1 length γ=r/L1.

According to Figure 3, the load relationships for the all the leaves can be written in terms of load equilibrium condition as follows. The directions of the forces of each leaf are established in the local coordinate. Because the moments on all leaves are seriously coupled with various parameters, the approximate moment expressions are employed.

The dimensionless load equations of even number leaves can be written as (3a)p2kcos[∑i=kn(θ2(i+1)-θ2i+1)]-f2ksin[∑i=kn(θ2(i+1)-θ2i+1)]=-λ2k2pd (3b)p2ksin[∑i=kn(θ2(i+1)-θ2i+1)]+f2kcos[∑i=kn(θ2(i+1)-θ2i+1)]=λ2k2fd m2k≈λ2kmd-λ2kfd<label>(3c)</label>

For the odd number leaves, the dimensionless load equilibrium conditions have the similar expression (4a)p2k-1cos[∑i=kn(θ2i-θ2i+1)]+f2k-1sin[∑i=kn(θ2i-θ2i+1)]=λ2k-12pd (4b)f2k-1cos[∑i=kn(θ2i-θ2i+1)]-p2k-1sin[∑i=kn(θ2i-θ2i+1)]=λ2k-12fd (4c)m2k-1≈-λ2k-1md+λ2k-1fd(1-λ2k-1)

For the last leaf with number 2n+1, the dimensionless load equilibrium condition can be depicted as (5a)p2n+1=λ2n+12pd (5b)f2n+1=λ2n+12fd (5c)m2n+1≈-λ2n+1md+λ2n+1fd(1-λ2k-1) where n is the pair quantity, λ2k is the length ratio between the even number leaves and leaf 1, λ2k-1 is the length ratio between the odd number leaves and leaf 1, and λ2n+1 is the length ratio between the last leaf and leaf 1.

As is well known, the displacement of each leaf end point is related to axial load p. But, because of the constraint releasing of the leaf-springs, the decomposed force pd is neglected in such calculation process. We can imagine that the neglected terms lead to a relative error, but a succinct stiffness equation is obtained. The trigonometric functions in equations (3) to (5) should be further simplified as 0 and 1 for parameters decoupling. The reduction forms between displacements and the decomposed forces for every leaf can be written as linear approximate relationship by equation (1). (6a)[δy2kθ2k]≈1ab-c2[b-c-ca][λ2k2fdλ2kmd-λ2kfd] (6b)[δy2k-1θ2k-1]≈1ab-c2[b-c-ca] ×[λ2k-12fd-λ2k-1md+λ2k-1(1-λ2k-1)fd] (6c)[δy2n+1θ2n+-1]≈1ab-c2[b-c-ca] ×[λc2fd-λ2n+1md+λ2n+1(1-λ2k-1)fd]

The displacement of the point that leaf 1 connecting the inner ring can be simply depicted as (7)[Δyθ]≈[∑k=1nΔy2k∑k=1nθ2k]+[∑k=1nΔy2k-1-∑k=1nθ2k-1]+[Δy2n+1-θ2n+1] +[∑k=1n(L2k∑i=kn(θ2(i+1)-θ2i+1))0] -[∑k=1n(L2k-1∑i=kn(θ2i-θ2i+1))0]

By the aforementioned simplification, equation (7) can be simplified and detailedly written as (8a)δy=∑k=1nλ2kδy2k+∑k=1nλ2k-1δy2k-1+λcδy2n+1 -λθ2n+1-λ(n-1)θ2k+1-nθ2k+θ2n+1 +(n-1)θ2k+1 (8b)θ=∑k=1nθ2k-∑k=1nθ2k-1-θ2n+1

Suppose that the leaves from number 2 to number 2n are the same in dimension as illustrated in Figure 3. The geometric parameters λ and λc can thus be written as follows (9a)λ2k(k=[1,n])=λ2k-1(k=[2,n])=λ (9b)λ2n+1=λc

Substituting equation (6) into equation (8), the following approximations are adopted (10a)θ=[nλ2-12λ2-2nλ+λ+λcλ-12λc2-λc-12 2nλ-λ+λc+1]T×[fdmd] (10b)δy=[23nλ3-13λ3+λcλ2-2nλ2+λ2-λc2λ -2λcλ+2nλ-λ+13λc3+λc2+λc+13 nλ2-12λ2-2nλ+λcλ+λ-12λc2-λc-12]T ×[fdmd]
For the force–displacements in such setup, the formulas reflecting geometric compatibility condition is expressed as (11)θ=tanθ=δyγ-δx≈δyγ

The following research shows that, neglecting higher order terms of θ is accurate enough to show the characteristics of the compliant pivot. Combining equations (10) and (11), the relationship between the decomposed forces fd and md can be expressed as in equation (12). (12)+5πcos(π.zl)lq5(t)}+(F0-ρAgz) ×{-π2sin(π.zl)l2q1(t)-4π2sin(π.zl)l2q2(t) -9π2sin(π.zl)l2q3(t)-16π2sin(π.zl)l2q4(t) -25π2sin(π.zl)l2q5(t)}=0

Combining equations (12), (10a) and (2), the analytical stiffness k (moment payload and rotational displacement ratio) can be expressed as (13)k=mθ=(8n-4)λ3+(12γ-24γn+12λc-24n+12)λ2 +(24γ2n-12γ2+48γn-24γ-24γλc-12λc2 -24λc+24n-12)λ+4λc3+12γλc2+12λc2 +12γ2λc+24γλc+12λc+12γ2+12γ+4(4n2-4n+1)λ4+(8n+8nλc-4λc-4)λ3+(-12nλc2-12n+12λc+6λc2+6)λ2+(8n+8nλc3-12λc-12λc2-4λc3-4)λ+λc4+4λc3+6λc2+4λc+1

As can be seen in equation (13), the parameters are seriously coupled. So, this analytical model is tedious for the designing of series–parallel leaves annulus-shaped compliant pivot. Furthermore, the model can be degenerated to the model as shown in Figure 4 for the design simplification because the parameter λc is zero. Equation (13) has just three parameters. If the leaves quantity in each pattern has been fixed, two parameters left. The degenerated model, which consists of the leaves with even number, is shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
A degenerative generalized annulus-shaped compliant pivot with series–parallel leaves.

The characteristics of analytical model should be legibly shown for understanding. Figure 5 shows the dimensionless stiffness varying with the structural parameters. The parameters for simulation in Figure 5(a) to (c) is with n=2. In Figure 5(a), λc=1, in Figure 5(b), λ=0.8, meanwhile, in Figure 5(c), γ=0.5, correspondingly, in Figure 5(d), λ=0.8. The other parameters are shown in ‘The FEA validation’ section Figure 5.
Characteristics of the dimensionless stiffness varying with the structural parameters.

As can be seen in Figure 5(a) and (b), with the increase of parameter γ, the stiffness increases dramatically. The reason can be explained as the strength of constraint of degree leading to ability decreasing of DOF. Figure 5(a) shows that the parameter λ does not effectively change the stiffness because the range of such a parameter is not evident, which means the whole effective strength of the module is not dramatically changed. Similarly, Figure 5(b) shows that the parameter λc has almost the same reason, i.e. the effective length do not change effectively. In Figure 5(c), with a fixed γ=0.5, the stiffness will decrease with the increasing λ because the effective length expands. In Figure 5(d), the dimensionless stiffness decreases with the increasing leaf numbers because the whole leaves length increase correspondingly. These illustrations are consistent with intuition, but should be validated by FEA analysis. This work is done in ‘The FEA validation’ section.

sec.title: Stress analysis
sec.p: Rotational range of the annulus compliant pivot with multi-leaves should be calculated to estimate the motion capability. The rotational angle of the pivot is the co-action of every leaf. Because of the series structure of every module in the annulus compliant pivot, the rotational range is equal to the angle sum of every leaf end angle, so the maximum rotational angle can be calculated by a single cantilever beam. The maximum rotational angle is decided by the weakest leaf, which is judged by the maximum stress that is obtained by the yield strength of material, Sy.

Generally, the leaf is treated as Euler–Bernoulli beam, because the length of leaf is much greater than the thickness, and the shearing effect is always ignored. For an Euler–Bernoulli beam, the maximum stress in every leaf is the sum of axial stress σai and maximum bending stress σbim, which are caused by axial force and bending moment, respectively. As aforementioned, the internal bending moment along the length of the leaf (x direction in the local coordinate) can be written as (14)mi(x)=mi+fi(1-x)+pi(yi(x)-δyi)(i=[1,2n+1])

The axial stress is always taken as constant along the length of the leaf, which can be easily written as (15)σai=Epid(i=[1,2n+1]) dis defined as d=12(L/T)2. As aforementioned, in such an annulus modeling, the decomposed force pi is always treated as very small because of the releasing of DOC (degree of constraint). So the axial stress can be ignored. Meanwhile, the bending moment along the leaf is simplified. Therefore, the maximum stress in every leaf, σi(i=[1,2n+1]) can be treated as (16)σi=|σbim|+|σai|≈|σbim|
The bending stress along the length of the leaf in the local coordinate can be written as (17)σbi=3Emi(x)d(i=[1,2n+1])
The maximum rotation angle can be obtained through checking the stress by comparing with the yield strength (Sy) (18)σm=maxσi(i=[1,2n+1])<Sy

The decomposed tangential force fi and bending moment mi are resolved in the section ‘The load–displacement behavior of an annulus-shaped compliant pivot’ and listed below. In these explanations, we define the following parameters: ff and mf denote the decomposed load on the end of first leaf, which is connected with the inner ring, fl and ml denote the decomposed load on the end of last leaf, which is connected with the outer ring, meanwhile, fe and me denote the decomposed load on the end of even number leaves, fo and mo denote the decomposed load on the end of odd number leaves except the first and the last one. ff=θ[(12-n)λ2+(2γn-γ+2n-λc-1)λ +12λc2+γλc+λc+γ+12]/Q(n,λ,λc,γ) mf=θ[(13-23n)λ3+(γn-12γ-λc+2n-1)λ2 +(γ-2γn+γλc+λc2+2λc-2n+1)λ -13λc3-12γλc2-λc2-γλc-λc-12γ-13]/ Q(n,λ,λc,γ) fe=fo=θ[(12-n)λ4+(2γn-γ+2n-λc-1)λ3 +(12λc2+γλc+λc+γ+12)λ2]/Q(n,λ,λc,γ) me=θ[(23n-13)λ4+(12γ-γn-n+λc+12)λ3 +(-γλc-λc2-λc)λ2 +(13λc3+12γλc2+12λc2-12γ-16)λ]/Q(n,λ,λc,γ) mo=θ[(13n-16)λ4+(12γ-γn-n+12)λ3 +(12λc2-γ-12)λ2 +(12γ-12γλc2-13λc3-12λc2+16)λ]/Q(n,λ,λc,γ) fl=θ[(12-n)λc2λ2+(2γn-γ+2n-λc-1)λc2λ+(12λc2+γλc+λc+γ+12)λc2]/Q(n,λ,λc,γ) ml=θ[(13nλc-16λc)λ3 +(12γλc-γnλc-nλc+12λc) λ2-γλcλ-13λc4-12γλc3-12λc3+12γλc+16λc]/ Q(n,λ,λc,γ) where Q(n,λ,λc,γ)=(13n2-13n+112)λ4 +(23n+23nλc-13-13λc)λ3 +(12-n-nλc2+λc+12λc2)λ2 +(23n+23nλc3-13λc3-λc2-λc-13)λ +112λc4+13λc3+12λc2+13λc+112

As seen in the simplification above, the parameters are selected as aforementioned simulation in stiffness characteristics. As in practical design, two structures are adopted usually, even number leaves and odd number leaves in each module corresponding to λc=0 and λc≠0. For λc≠0 condition, λc=1 is always employed for simplification. Thus, λc=0 and λc=1 are simulated. In this simulation, the rotation angle is 0.2 rad.

If λc (0 and 1), θ (0.2 rad) and n= 2 are fixed (Figure 6), two parameters (λ and γ) are left in the stress equations. One axis in the three-dimensional graphs depicts one of them while the other axis denotes the dimensionless leaf length in their local coordinate from 0 to 1. For λc=0, the plane of σbe is on the top while the plane of σbf is below, which means when x=0, even number leaves have the maximum stress while the first leaf has the largest stress when x=1. For λc=1, the plane of σbe always intersect that of σbl plane if λ is small or γ is large (dashed line depict the intersection). According to the decomposed loads in ‘Stress analysis’ section, the reason can be explained as small λ and large γ, meaning smaller loads on the even number leaves. Figure 6.
Characteristics of the bending stress in each leaf varying with the structural parameters.

sec.title: The FEA validation
sec.p:
In order to examine the validity of analytical characteristics above, the commercial finite element analysis (FEA) program is used. The ANSYS element for simulation is adopted as beam 3, whose note has 3 motional degrees of freedom. The shape parameters and material properties for each compliant pivot are listed in Table 1. For each pivot, the width and thickness (T is the leaf thickness) are the same for all leaves. Table 1.
Shape parameters of the leaves and Young’s modulus of the material for general annulus-shaped compliant pivot.
D (mm) L1 (mm) T (mm) W (mm) E (Pa)
3 50 1 5 73e9

First of all, the stiffness characteristic is simulated. The length of the leaf, which is connected with the inner loop is fixed as 50 mm. The parameter n is fixed as 2, which means each module has 4 leaves if λc=0, meanwhile, each module has 5 leaves if λc≠0. The parameters λ and γ are selected within the range as simulated above. λ is chosen as 0.7, 0.8, 0.9 and γ is selected as 0.25, 0.5 and 1. The parameter D is 3 mm in simulation model, which is smaller compared to the leaf dimension. These adopted parameters are practical in annulus pivot designing.

In order to verify the accuracy of the model, the relative error is defined by using the FEA data, which are treated as precise (19)er=|θm-θFEA||θFEA| where er indicates the relative error, θm denotes the rotational displacement of analytical model and θFEA is the data simulated by FEA.

A general 3D model of module that is simulated in ANSYS can be seen in Figure 7 in which the deformed model is also included. In the simulation, Point 1 is fixed and the imposed moment load is imposed on point 2. In addition, the connection parts (in the circles), which are regarded as rigid are far more stiffer than the effective leaves. Figure 7.
A 3D simulation model in ANSYS and the deformed model.

In Figure 8, the parameter λ and λc are fixed as 0.8 and 1, respectively. Three numerical values of γ (0.25, 0.5 and 1) are simulated. We can easily find that the dimensionless stiffness increases with increasing γ. As explained above, a larger γ means a strengthened degree of constraint (DOC). It is amazing that the relative error for γ=0.5 is steadily below 0.5%. For γ=0.25 with the rotation range below 0.1, the relative error changes acutely. For γ=1, the relative error increases with the expanding of rotation angle, because a strengthened DOC is sensitive with the predigestion. For example, the effect of omitted decomposed axial load will become larger with increasing γ, so with the increasing rotation angle, the larger γ is more impressible. Figure 8.
(a) Rotation displacement for different γ, and (b) stiffness relative errors.

As can be seen in Figure 9, when λ and γ are fixed as 0.8 and 0.5, respectively, λc=0 and λc=1 are validated because these two numerical values are practical in structure design. It is visible that the stiffness for λc=0 is larger than that for λc=1 because λc=0 corresponding to 4 leaves in each module while 5 leaves for λc=1, the effective leaf length is evidently shorter. With these simulation numerical values, the relative errors for a rotation angle below 0.2 rad are small, which is generally less than 1.5%. Figure 9.
(a) Rotation displacement for different λc, and (b) stiffness relative errors.

Figure 10 shows the stiffness and relative error characteristics for variances of λ with λc=1 and γ=0.5. With the increasing of λ, the stiffness of the module becomes smaller. The reason can be explained as the effective lengths changing just as aforementioned. Long effective leaf length accords to large compliant and a released constraint. With the rotation angle expanding, the relative error for λ=0.7 gets large and becomes smaller for λ=0.9. This phenomenon maybe associated with the constraint diversification. Figure 10.
(a) Rotation displacement for different λ, and (b) stiffness relative errors.

Finally, the bending stress in every leaf is verified by FEA simulation, as depicted in Figure 11. Two models are simulated with θ=0.2. In Figure 11(a), the parameters are γ=0.5, λ=0.8 and λc=0. The parameter x for every leaf is in their local coordinate. As known above, the leaves with even or odd numbers (except leaf 1) have the same stress equation for simplifying, so the stress lines for leaf 2 and leaf 4, which is obtained from analytical model are superposable. The corresponding data for leaf 2 and leaf 4 derived by FEA are similar that validate the correction of assumption. The stress lines for odd number leaves (except leaf 1) and even number leaves are seemed parallel as the bending moments have a constant difference with fixed parameters as can be seen by equations in the section ‘Stress analysis’. In Figure 11(b), the parameters are γ=0.25, λ=0.8 and λc=1, the stress trend except the last leaf in accordance with that in Figure 11(a). The stress line of the last leaf intersects the stress lines of even number leaves. These curves accord with the illustrations by three dimension graphs in the ‘Stress analysis’ section. Figure 11.
The stress distribution along the length of every leaf.

On all accounts, these simplified artifices lead to relative error, which is difficult to avoid. As the case stands, the model data agree with the FEA data quite well. The analytical model can still provide an effective method for the aforehand design.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: General module with paralleled leaves in series used in ASCP was first developed to provide parametric insight into the load–displacement behavior. As seen in ASCP, this structure can undergo a special displacement constraint because the point connecting with the inner ring or outer ring rotates on a circle track, which leads to a special geometric compatibility condition. The module is an over-constraint system. We can easily understand why the conventional ASCP with just one leaf in a module has a linear load–displacement relationship always below 1°. Consequently, within a determinate space (the outer ring dimension is fixed), enlarging the effective leaves length may release the constraint. This can be achieved by increasing the pairs of paralleled leaves, lengthening every leaf length and decreasing the radius of inner ring. Released constraint means a better linearization for the load–displacement behavior, which is always commercioganic for large-displacement pivots design.

Meanwhile, the stress characteristics in every leaf are analyzed for predicting the rotation range based on the decomposed loads. The bending stress on two points should be checked in this model. Firstly, the point where the leaf connects with the inner ring is always suffering from a rigorous bending stress. The other one is not steady. For the module with even number leaves, the maximum bending stress on other leaf end occurs on the last leaf which connects with the outer ring. But for the module with odd number leaves, when the radius of inner ring is short enough and the leaves between the first and last leaf are long enough, this other maximum bending stress is in the even number leaves.

The stiffness and stress analysis are based on the approximate formulas of a beam flexure and are validated by FEA method, which shows that the models are accurate enough when the angle is up to 0.2 rad. The load–displacement behavior curves delivers almost straight-line and the relative errors in the simulation are always below 5% or even less. Evidently, the proposed model is univocal and can provide quick calculation and parametric insights into the annulus-shaped compliant pivot design, which is composed by this kind of module.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This article was supported by the National Natural Science Foundations of China (approved grants: 50975007and 51105014).

ref.citation: Smith ST. Flexures: elements of elastic mechanisms, New York: Gordon and Breach Science, 2000.
